Description.val:
The COMPASS CALL capability is the USAF's premier wide-area coverage Airborne Electronic Attack (AEA) Offensive Counter Information (OCI) weapon system. In order to ensure continued tactical effectiveness COMPASS CALL's Prime Mission Equipment (PME) must evolve to keep pace with emerging adversary developments in communications, radar, and sensor technology as well as the use of rapidly advancing commercial communications technology. To meet this challenge the COMPASS CALL program employs an incremental Baseline upgrade acquisition strategy that puts capability into the warfighter's hands as soon as practical and ensures each iteration of the weapon system is effective against the highest priority threats. Capabilities inserted into each Baseline are planned in advance, based on war-fighter inputs. Executive Management Reviews are held to review and set the expectation for the Baseline content as production nears.  Procurement funds are required for modification kit production (hardware, firmware, and software), installation, certification, and test on a re-host platform in accordance with the Baseline upgrade cyclic schedule. 

As of first quarter FY 2019, the COMPASS CALL EC-130H fleet consists of two (2) Baseline 1 (BL1) aircraft, ten (10) Mid-Baseline 2 (MBL2) aircraft, and one (1) MBL2 test aircraft.  One of the (1) MBL2 aircraft is in depot receiving Programmed Depot Maintenance (PDM) and modification of the Avionics Viability Program (AVP, glass cockpit).  In late FY 2018, two (2) BL1 aircraft were divested (one was inducted into AMARG, one
was provided to a museum). Additional BL1 aircraft will divest in FY 2019 and FY 2020. EC-130H aircraft baseline upgrade modification efforts will be complete with MBL2. The MBL2 efforts focus on reliability
and sustainability improvements, obsolescence replacement, weight reduction, simplification of PME operations and maintenance, and electronic attack capability increases.
  
In addition to these aircraft the program also includes one (1) EC-130H Weapon System Trainer (WST, flight deck simulator) and two (2) COMPASS CALL Mission Crew Simulators (CCMCS). With each Baseline, efforts focus on reliability and sustainability improvements, obsolescence resolution, weight reduction, simplification of PME operations and maintenance, and increased electronic attack capabilities. 

Beginning in FY 2017, with the transition to the Baseline 3 (BL3) re-host effort, the program of record added one (1) aircraft (known as EC-37B) which was procured in late FY 2017.  A second aircraft was procured in late FY 2018 and the third and fourth are projected to be procured in FY 2019.  These four aircraft will receive a mix of legacy PME from donor EC-130H aircraft as well as new, upgraded PME. Procurement of the air vehicles for re-host is performed under the Aircraft Procurement, Air Force appropriation, Budget Activity 04, Budget Sub Activity 05 under P-1 Line Item Number: CALL00/COMPASS CALL.
 
COMPASS CALL modification efforts include, but are not limited to, the Counter Radar Subsystem; third generation Special Purpose Emitter Array (SPEAR) subsystem; and other systems necessary to counter modern commercial and military communications, navigation, radar, and other threats in the electromagnetic spectrum; as well as aircraft and PME retrofits. Baseline upgrades and enhancements will also include necessary support equipment, training device/simulator modifications, test and test support activities (planning, integration). The simulators provide for the training and qualification of aircrew and ground personnel as well as address training obsolescence issues. 

FY 2018 funding totals include $56.72M for Overseas Contingency Operations (OCO): $28.12M is included in the P-3A for Mod Number 1001 (COMPASS CALL) and $28.6M is included in in the P-3A for Mod Number 1003 (COMPASS CALL Baseline 3).

FY 2019 funding totals include $36.4M for OCO, it is included in the P-3A for Mod Number 1001 (COMPASS CALL).
 
Due to the rapidly changing threat environment encountered in overseas contingency operations, the acquisition program manager has the authority to redirect funding, as necessary, to meet currently slated and/or emerging Combatant Commander requirements through the integration of Quick Reaction Capability (QRC) kits and other high-priority efforts. 

Funding for this exhibit is contained in PE 0207253F.

As directed in the FY 2018 NDAA, Sec 825, amendment to PL 114-92 FY 2016 NDAA, Sec 828 Penalty for Cost Overruns, the FY 2018 Air Force penalty total is $14.373M. The calculated percentage reduction to each research, development, test and evaluation and procurement account will be allocated proportionally from all programs, projects, or activities under such account.

Justification.val: Where applicable, justification for individual modifications is provided in the P-3A exhibits.

Description.val:
The COMPASS CALL capability is the USAF's premier wide-area coverage Airborne Electronic Attack (AEA) Offensive Counter Information (OCI) weapon system. In order to ensure continued tactical effectiveness COMPASS CALL's Prime Mission Equipment (PME) must evolve to keep pace with emerging adversary developments in communications, radar, and sensor technology as well as the use of rapidly advancing commercial communications technology. To meet this challenge the COMPASS CALL program employs an incremental Baseline upgrade acquisition strategy that puts capability into the warfighter's hands as soon as practical and ensures each iteration of the weapon system is effective against the highest priority threats. Capabilities inserted into each Baseline are planned in advance, based on war-fighter inputs. Executive Management Reviews are held to review and set the expectation for Baseline content as production nears. Both modification kit components and integration costs for a given Baseline upgrade are procured in the first fiscal year (FY) of execution and installed the next year. Procurement funds are required for modification kit production (hardware, firmware, and software) to include software integration lab components, installation, certification, and test on a re-host platform in accordance with the Baseline upgrade cyclic schedule.
 
As of first quarter FY 2019, the COMPASS CALL EC-130H fleet consists of two (2) Baseline 1 (BL1) aircraft, ten (10) Mid-Baseline 2 (MBL2) aircraft and one (1) MBL2 test aircraft. One (1) MBL2 aircraft is in depot receiving Programmed Depot Maintenance (PDM) and modification of the Avionics Viability Program (AVP, glass cockpit) upgrade. In addition to these aircraft the program also includes one (1) EC-130H Weapon System Trainer (WST, flight deck simulator) and two (2) COMPASS CALL Mission Crew Simulators (CCMCS). In late FY 2018, two (2) BL1 aircraft were divested (one was inducted into AMARG, one was provided to a museum). Additional BL1 aircraft will divest in FY 2019 and FY 2020. EC-130H aircraft baseline upgrade modification efforts will be complete with MBL2.  The MBL2 efforts focus on reliability and sustainability improvements, obsolescence replacement, weight reduction, simplification of PME operations and maintenance, and electronic attack capability increases. 

Transitioning to the re-host effort, the program of record procured two (2) commercial derivative aircraft (known as EC-37B); one was procured in late FY 2017 and one in late FY 2018. Two (2) aircraft will be procured in FY 2019, and one (1) aircraft will be procured in FY 2020, bringing the program of record to five (5) commercial derivative aircraft. These five aircraft will receive Prime Mission Equipment (PME) from legacy donor EC-130H aircraft, as well as new, upgraded PME. The FY20 budget request supports the procurement of Group A and prime mission equipment (Group B), installation of Group A/B, support equipment which includes test program sets, Compass Call Mission Crew Simulator upgrades and program management administration (PMA) requirements. Procurement and installation of the BL3 PME modification kits onto those air vehicles is performed under this line item (CALL00/Modification Number 1003). Procurement of the air vehicles for re-host is performed under the Aircraft Procurement, Air Force appropriation, Budget Activity 04, Budget Sub Activity 05 under P-1 Line Item Number: CALL00/COMPASS CALL. 
 
COMPASS CALL modification efforts include, but are not limited to, the Counter Radar Subsystem; next generation Special Purpose Emitter Array (SPEAR) subsystem; and aircraft and PME retrofits. Baseline upgrades and enhancements will also include necessary support equipment, training device/simulator modifications, test and test support activities (planning, integration). The simulators provide for the training and qualification of aircrew and ground personnel as well as address training obsolescence issues. 

In FY 2018, Mod Number 1003 includes $28.6M of the $56.72M total CALL00 OCO funding. This funding is for SPEAR Generation 3 capability and is included in the Group B kit procurement line. The remaining $28.12M is included in the P-3A for Mod Number 1001 (COMPASS CALL).

The Group B amount in FY 2018 is for the SPEAR Generation 3 capability identified in the OCO paragraph above and prime mission equipment for the Systems Integration Laboratory (SIL).  The third and fourth aircraft Group B will be procured in FY 2019. The fifth aircraft Group B kit will be procured in FY 2020.   

Due to the rapidly changing threat environment encountered in combat operations, the acquisition program manager has the authority to redirect funding as necessary to meet currently stated and/ or emerging Combatant Commander requirements through the integration of Quick Reaction Capability (QRC) kits and other high-priority efforts.
 
Funding for this exhibit is contained in PE 0207253F.

Milestone/Development Status

The COMPASS CALL weapon system is continuously improved using a rapid development and acquisition process supporting a Baseline upgrade strategy. User needs and technology opportunities are continuously reviewed. The COMPASS CALL Baseline 3 configuration will begin initial fielding in 2023.
